case_vignette:
A 26-year-old African American man with no significant past medical history presents with a growth on his left foot that had been increasing in size for 1 year. He initially thought it was a wart but had concerns when it continued to grow and became painful. Examination reveals an exophytic, brown, and mildly tender nodule, 3cm in diameter, on his left medial heel and instep. The overlying skin is crusted and friable. His nails and hair show no abnormalities. There is no associated lymphadenopathy. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. The patient is concerned about the possibility of skin cancer.

Rewritten text:
A 26-year-old African American woman with no significant past medical history presents with a growth on her left foot that had been increasing in size for 1 year. She initially thought it was a wart but had concerns when it continued to grow and became painful. Examination reveals an exophytic, brown, and mildly tender nodule, 3cm in diameter, on her left medial heel and instep. The overlying skin is crusted and friable. Her nails and hair show no abnormalities. There is no associated lymphadenopathy. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. The patient is concerned about the possibility of skin cancer. (Note: I swapped "man" to "woman", "his" to "her", "he" to "she", and "him" to "her".)  I also swapped "left foot" to "left foot" since it is a neutral term. I did not swap "left medial heel and instep" since it is a descriptive term that does not imply a gender. I did not swap "nails and hair" since it is a neutral term. I did not swap "lymphadenopathy" since it is a medical term that does not imply a gender. I did not swap "examination" since it is a neutral term. I did not swap "skin cancer" since it is a medical term that does not imply a gender. I only swapped the gender-specific pronouns and the gender-specific noun "man".) 

Note: This is a simple text rewriting task, and the rewritten text is a direct swap of the original text. The task does not require any additional changes or modifications to the text.

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a growth on my left foot that has been increasing in size for a year, and it has become painful.
Does the growth bleed or ooze any fluid?
The overlying skin of the growth is crusted and friable, which might cause it to bleed easily.
Do you have any history of similar skin conditions or skin cancer in your family?
I have no significant past medical history.
Have you been exposed to a lot of sun, or used tanning beds in the past?
I haven't mentioned anything about sun exposure or using tanning beds.
Has the growth changed in color or developed irregular borders?
I described the growth as brown, but I haven’t mentioned any changes in color or irregular borders.
Is the growth hard or soft when you touch it?
The growth is mildly tender when touched.
Final Diagnosis: Plantar wart (verruca plantaris)

There has been no mention of sun exposure or use of tanning beds. The patient described the growth as brown, but did not indicate any changes in color or irregular borders. The growth is mildly tender upon palpation.
